blurb: Beginning with good friendship, the Buddha teaches nine things that give rise to the qualities that lead to awakening.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: The things that a mendicant relies on as supports in spiritual practice.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Venerable Meghiya, while attending on the Buddha, wants to go off and meditate in a forest alone. The Buddha discourages him, but he goes anyway. When his meditation doesn’t go well, he returns chastened to the Buddha, who teaches him about the benefits of good companions and other fundamentals of a balanced spiritual practice.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nandaka is teaching the monks when the Buddha arrives. Unbeknown to those inside, the Buddha waits until the talk was finished, then enters. Nandaka is embarrassed at keeping the Buddha waiting, but the Buddha praises him and offers a teaching on the four things a mendicant should complete. Nandaka then teaches five benefits of listening to Dhamma.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: A noble disciple who develops four powers overcomes five fears.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Four kinds of person who one should or should not associate with. A similar distinction is made regarding robes, almsfood, lodgings, towns, and countries.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: The wanderer Sutavā asks the Buddha about five things a perfected one cannot do; the Buddha expands it to nine.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: The wanderer Sajjha asks the Buddha about five things a perfected one cannot do; the Buddha expands it to nine, which differ slightly from AN 9.7.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine kinds of persons: the eight noble persons and the ordinary person.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine persons are worthy of gifts: the eight noble persons and a member of the spiritual family.
translated_title: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods

translations.author: Sabbamitta
translations.title: Einer den Göttern gewidmeten Gabe würdig

translations.author: Bhikkhu Sujato
translations.title: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

translated_title: The Chapter on the Lion’s Roar

blurb: After the rains season, Sāriputta takes leave of the Buddha. Another monk falsely accuses Sāriputta of hitting him before leaving. The Buddha calls Sāriputta to answer the accusation. Before the Saṅgha, Sāriputta denies it, uttering a powerful statement of spiritual prowess.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Sāriputta visits some wanderers, who claim that only perfected ones are free from bad rebirth. Sāriputta has no opinion on this, but asks the Buddha, who replies that even stream-enterers are freed from lower rebirth.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Venerables Mahākoṭṭhita and Sāriputta discuss whether the spiritual path is for the purpose of changing the results of deeds.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Sāriputta questions Venerable Samiddhi on the basis of intentions and thoughts.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: The body is compared to a boil with nine orifices.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine perceptions to be developed in meditation.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine factors in how a family relates to the Saṅgha.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine factors for a glorious sabbath: the eight precepts and the meditation on love.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Some deities come to the Buddha and speak of how their practice in their past life was limited and unsatisfactory.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: The wealthy and devoted lay supporter Anāthapiṇḍika rather curiously says that only poor alms are given in his home. The Buddha praises gracious and bounteous generosity. But meditation surpasses even the greatest offering.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

translated_title: The Chapter on Abodes of Sentient Beings

blurb: A comparison of the people of India, of Uttarakuru, and of the heaven of the Thirty-Three.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine kinds of horses are compared with nine kinds of monks.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine things that are rooted in craving.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine realms into which sentient beings may be reborn.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine reflections by which a mendicant knows their mind has wisdom.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Venerables Candikāputta and Sāriputta differ in their interpretation of a teaching proposed by the notorious schismatic Devadatta.
translated_title: The Simile of the Stone Pillar

translations.author: Bhikkhu Sujato
translations.title: The Simile of the Stone Pillar

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: A householder who has eliminated the perils that come with breaking the five precepts, and possesses the four factors of stream-entry is freed from lower rebirths.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: A householder who has eliminated the perils that come with breaking the five precepts, and possesses the four factors of stream-entry is freed from lower rebirths.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine grounds for resentment.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine ways of removing resentment.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine meditative states, each of which arises from the cessation of something present in the previous state.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine progressive meditation states.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Nine progressive meditation states, explained in detail.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Sāriputta declares that extinguishment is bliss, precisely because nothing is felt there. He explains this apparent paradox with reference to the nine progressive meditations.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Just as a foolish cow can get in trouble wandering the mountains, a foolish mendicant can get lost practicing absorption if they do it wrongly.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: The ending of defilements happens due to the practice of absorption meditation.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Ānanda exclaims how amazing it is that the Buddha has found a way to freedom while still experiencing the world. Questioned by the monk Udāyī, Ānanda recounts a discussion on advanced meditation with the nun Jaṭilagāhiyā.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Two brahmin cosmologists ask the Buddha to decide between competing claims as to whether the cosmos is infinite. Rejecting metaphysical claims, the Buddha says that there is no end of the world that can be reached by traveling; but without reaching the end of the world you can’t be free of suffering.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: In the wars between gods and demons, they find safety only in their own fortress. Similarly, a mendicant finds safety in absorption.
translated_title: The War Between the Gods and the Titans

translations.author: Sabbamitta
translations.title: Die Schlacht zwischen Göttern und Titanen

translations.author: Bhikkhu Sujato
translations.title: The War Between the Gods and the Titans

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: A bull elephant, annoyed by living in the herd, goes off by himself. Similarly, a mendicant feeling crowded in a monastery goes off by themselves and happily meditates in seclusion.
translated_title: The Simile of the Bull Elephant in the Forest

translations.author: Sabbamitta
translations.title: Das Gleichnis vom Elefantenbullen im Wald

translations.author: Bhikkhu Sujato
translations.title: The Simile of the Bull Elephant in the Forest

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: The householder Tapussa reflects that it is renunciation that distinguishes lay from monastic. The Buddha responds by giving a long account of his practice of absorption before awakening.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: At Udāyī’s request, Ānanda explains an obscure verse spoken (in SN 2.7) by a deity. The nine progressive meditations are the escape from confinement.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: The Buddha speaks of a “direct witness’, that is, someone who personally has thorough and proficient experience of the different meditation states.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: One liberated by wisdom first enters the meditation states, then understands them.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: One freed both ways is both proficient in and understands the meditation states.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: The teaching apparent in the present life is experienced provisionally in deep meditation, and completely when the defilements end.

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Extinguishment apparent in the present life is experienced provisionally in deep meditation, and completely when the defilements end.
translated_title: Extinguishment Is Apparent in the Present Life

translations.author: Sabbamitta
translations.title: Das Erlöschen ist in diesem Leben ersichtlich

translations.author: Bhikkhu Sujato
translations.title: Extinguishment Is Apparent in the Present Life
